section.title: The passive
section.sectiontitle: In active sentences, the subject is the 'doer' of the verb. In passive sentences, the subject is not the 'doer' of the verb.
section.text1: active: the subject (the firefighter) is the 'doer':
section.text2: passive: the subject (the child) is not the 'doer':
section.text2a: The child was rescued by the firefighter.
section.sectiontitle2: We use the passive to focus on the main topic of the sentence. This is usually at the beginning.
section.text3: The sentence is mainly about the Olympic gold medal; we use the passive:
section.text3a: The Olympic gold medal was won by Jackson.
section.text4: The sentence is mainly about Jackson; we use the active:

section.title: The passive
section.sectiontitle: We use the passive if the 'doer' of the verb is unknown or unimportant, or it is obvious who does the action.
section.text1: We don't know who stole my bag:
section.text2: It's obvious that the police arrested the people:
section.sectiontitle2: If we mention the 'doer' of the verb we use by + the person.
section.text3a: The building was designed by Sir Andrew Rowley.

section.title: The passive
section.sectiontitle: In the positive, we use be + past participle.
section.text1a: Ten films have been made so far this year.
section.sectiontitle2: In the negative, we use be + not + past participle. In the question, we use be + subject + past participle.
